Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ultimate goal of this research is to create a low-resource, comprehensive two-dimensional gas chromatographic microsystem prototype comprised entirely of Si-micromachined components that uses an extant, proof-of-concept, 2-stage microfabricated thermal modulator.
Intellectual Merit: Comprehensive two-dimensional gas chromatography is arguably the most effective method known for separating and detecting the components of extremely complex mixtures of S/VOCs.
Broader Impacts: The successful project will extend the state-of-the-art in small, inexpensive, turn-key instrumentation for identifying/quantifying organic compounds in complex mixtures. This is a natural extension of previous collaborative work involving students/faculty from mechanical/electrical engineering, chemistry, applied physics, and environmental health sciences, which will promote interdisciplinary mentoring/learning in microsystem integration, separation science, and public health.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was highly successful and the broad goals set forth at the outset were met: we have developed a laboratory prototype instrument capable of performing comprehensive two-dimensional gas chromatographic analyses (µGC×µGC) of complex mixtures wherein all essential analytical components are microfabricated.  At the core of the microsystem is a 2-stage microfabricated thermal modulator (µTM), which is placed at the juncture of the 1st- and 2nd-dimension separation stages.  We have shown that a room-temperature ionic liquid (RTIL) could be used as a thermally stable stationary phase within the µTM, but that its retention was too low for practical applications.  Using an alternative polymeric stationary phase in the µTM, we demonstrated that temperature programming the µTM independently from the separation µcolumns significantly enhances performance and broadens the range of analytes that can be effectively separated. We showed that a new single-channel sensor technology based on an opto-fluidic ring resonator (µOFRR) can serve as an effective µGC×µGC detector, but that response speed and sensitivity depend inversely on the vapor pressure of the analyte. We also showed that an array of nanoparticle coated chemiresistor sensors could also serve as an effective µGC×µGC detector, with the added value brought by the response pattern generated from the array, which effectively adds another (i.e., 3rd) dimension to the analyses. Equipped with either of the microsensor technologies, the µGC×µGC is capable of quantitatively analyzing the components of volatile organic compound (VOC) mixtures.   

With respect to broader impacts, this project has contributed significantly to meeting the need for small, inexpensive, turn-key instrumentation for identifying/quantifying trace-level VOCs in complex mixtures.  Such instrumentation is critical to numerous applications requiring such analytical capabilities in field or clinical settings, e.g., breath biomarker determinations, explosives detection, personal exposure monitoring, and military surveillance.  Several scientific and engineering aspects of the processes, devices, and materials developed here were elucidated and optimized, while others that were revealed in the course of study remain to be resolved in the future. The students, post-doctoral fellows, technical staff, and faculty on the project team represented several disciplines/perspectives (i.e., electrical and mechanical engineering, applied physics, chemistry, and environmental health sciences), which promoted interdisciplinary learning in nano/microfabrication, separation science, physical and analytical chemistry, materials science, and environmental (public) health.  Dissemination of project results to representatives of technology-oriented companies and leading research centers in microsystems was facilitated through the Michigan Center for Wireless Integrated Microsensing and Systems (WIMS2). This affiliation promoted the transfer of the developed technologies toward practical application and further expanded the scope and value of training provided to the students.  A certificate degree program in Environmental Monitoring Microsystems was defined in parallel with the research performed in this project, with the goal of enhancing the cross-disciplinary graduate-level education relevant to the careers of many science and engineering students.

 


Last Modified: 11/19/2017
Modified by: Edward T Zellers

Images (1 of )
  • 2-D contour plot of unleaded gasoline analyzed using the temperature programmed µTM with conventional separation columns (FID). Colored lines represent compound-class bands (e.g., black = alkanes). Specific compounds (1-11) were identified by retention time matching with authentic samples.
    author
    Copyrighted
    Edward T Zellers
    Figure 2
  • a) block diagram of the µGC x µGC microsystem with photographs of the microdevices (sans micropreconcentrator-focuser; µPCF); b) photograph of the completed µGC x µGC prototype, including µPCF and chemiresistor (µCR) sensor array.
    author
    Public Domain
    Edward T Zellers
    Figure 1
  • µGC x µGC contour plots of an 11-VOC mixture with a) polymer-coated µOFRR detection and b) FID. Overlayed boxes are visual guides to the structure of each chromatogram: alkanes (blue), aromatics (black), and oxygenates (red).
    author
    Copyrighted
    Edward T Zellers
    Figure 3
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project was highly successful and the broad goals set forth at the outset were met: we have developed a laboratory prototype instrument capable of performing comprehensive two-dimensional gas chromatographic analyses (µGC×µGC) of complex mixtures wherein all essential analytical components are microfabricated. At the core of the microsystem is a 2-stage microfabricated thermal modulator (µTM), which is placed at the juncture of the 1st- and 2nd-dimension separation stages. We have shown that a room-temperature ionic liquid (RTIL) could be used as a thermally stable stationary phase within the µTM, but that its retention was too low for practical applications. Using an alternative polymeric stationary phase in the µTM, we demonstrated that temperature programming the µTM independently from the separation µcolumns significantly enhances performance and broadens the range of analytes that can be effectively separated. We showed that a new single-channel sensor technology based on an opto-fluidic ring resonator (µOFRR) can serve as an effective µGC×µGC detector, but that response speed and sensitivity depend inversely on the vapor pressure of the analyte. We also showed that an array of nanoparticle coated chemiresistor sensors could also serve as an effective µGC×µGC detector, with the added value brought by the response pattern generated from the array, which effectively adds another (i.e., 3rd) dimension to the analyses. Equipped with either of the microsensor technologies, the µGC×µGC is capable of quantitatively analyzing the components of volatile organic compound (VOC) mixtures. With respect to broader impacts, this project has contributed significantly to meeting the need for small, inexpensive, turn-key instrumentation for identifying/quantifying trace-level VOCs in complex mixtures. Such instrumentation is critical to numerous applications requiring such analytical capabilities in field or clinical settings, e.g., breath biomarker determinations, explosives detection, personal exposure monitoring, and military surveillance. Several scientific and engineering aspects of the processes, devices, and materials developed here were elucidated and optimized, while others that were revealed in the course of study remain to be resolved in the future. The students, post-doctoral fellows, technical staff, and faculty on the project team represented several disciplines/perspectives (i.e., electrical and mechanical engineering, applied physics, chemistry, and environmental health sciences), which promoted interdisciplinary learning in nano/microfabrication, separation science, physical and analytical chemistry, materials science, and environmental (public) health. Dissemination of project results to representatives of technology-oriented companies and leading research centers in microsystems was facilitated through the Michigan Center for Wireless Integrated Microsensing and Systems (WIMS2). This affiliation promoted the transfer of the developed technologies toward practical application and further expanded the scope and value of training provided to the students. A certificate degree program in Environmental Monitoring Microsystems was defined in parallel with the research performed in this project, with the goal of enhancing the cross-disciplinary graduate-level education relevant to the careers of many science and engineering students.
